    Modelling

    Modelling.Rmd
    library(individual)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'individual'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     simulate
library(ggplot2)

    Creating an epidemiological models

    This article will walk you through the steps to create a basic SIR model, the hello world of epidemiology. In doing so you will learn how to define, simulate, analyse and make changes to your model.

    Defining the model structure

    This part allows researchers to get a basic idea of what you are modelling. You clearly define the states you are interested in modelling and initialise the numbers of individuals beginning in each state.

    Specifying your model also allows the “individual” package to build the data structures to handle your simulation.

    Defining the processes

    population <- 1 * 100 * 1000
S <- State$new('S', population)
I <- State$new('I', 0)
R <- State$new('R', 0)
human <- Individual$new('human', list(S, I, R))

    Defining the processes

    Now let’s specify how individuals move between states.

    In “individual”, we can do that with “processes”. They run every timestep and specify model updates based on the current state of the model.

    Process functions take 3 arguments:

    • frame, a SimFrame which exposes the current model state
    • timestep, an integer representing the current timestep
    • parameters, a list of user specified model parameters

    Some of these processes can be repetitive, so it is often a good idea to generate these functions, as demonstrated below:

    random_transition_generator <- function(from, to, rate) {
  function(frame, timestep, parameters) {
    from_state <- frame$get_state(human, from)
    StateUpdate$new(
      human,
      to,
      from_state[runif(length(from_state)) < rate]
    )
  }
}

processes <- list(
  random_transition_generator(S, I, .3),
  random_transition_generator(I, R, .5),
  random_transition_generator(R, S, .1)
)

    Running the simulation

    To see the model output, you simply run simulate. It will return a Simulation object, which you can analyse however you want.

    simulation <- simulate(human, processes, 100)
rendered <- simulation$render(human)

plot_states <- function(output) {
  df <- rbind(
    data.frame(
      counts = colSums(rendered$states == 'S'),
      timestep = 1:100,
      state = 'S'
    ),
    data.frame(
      counts = colSums(rendered$states == 'I'),
      timestep = 1:100,
      state = 'I'
    ),
    data.frame(
      counts = colSums(rendered$states == 'R'),
      timestep = 1:100,
      state = 'R'
    )
  )

  ggplot(
    df,
    aes(x = timestep, y = counts, group = state)
  ) + geom_line(aes(color = state))
}

plot_states(rendered)

    Adding Variables

    Quite often you will want to model continuous variables. These variables are affected by the environment and can in turn affect state changes.

    Let’s take immunity for example. We could decide that it should be acquired when individuals individuals recover from infection and should reduce the chances of immune individuals from becoming re-infected.

    We would first want to update our model structure…

    immunity <- Variable$new('immunity', function(size) 0)
human <- Individual$new(
  'human',
  list(S, I, R),
  variables = list(immunity)
)

    Here we initialise all levels of immunity to 0.

    We can then start to describe how this affects our processes…

    infection <- function(frame, timestep, parameters) {
  from_state <- frame$get_state(human, S)
  rate_modifier <- 1 - frame$get_variable(human, immunity)[from_state]
  rate <- .3
  StateUpdate$new(
    human,
    I,
    from_state[runif(length(from_state)) < (rate * rate_modifier)]
  )
}

recovery <- function(frame, timestep, parameters) {
  from_state <- frame$get_state(human, I)
  rate <- .2
  recovered <- from_state[runif(length(from_state)) < rate]
  list(
    StateUpdate$new(
      human,
      R,
      recovered
    ),
    VariableUpdate$new(
      human,
      immunity,
      parameters$immunity_level,
      recovered
    )
  )
}

processes_with_immunity <- list(
  infection,
  random_transition_generator(I, R, .5),
  recovery
)

    There are two new features in this example that have not yet been mentioned:

    1. Notice how the recovery process returns a list of updates. This allows it to boost immunity as well as change the same individuals’ states.
    2. We have used the parameters, object to specify the immunity level to set. This can be specified when we decide to run the simulation.

    You can see how this affects our outputs by re-simulating the model.

    rendered <- simulate(
  human,
  processes_with_immunity,
  100,
  list(immunity_level = .6)
)$render(human)
plot_states(rendered)

    You could also analyse the variables in your population.

    Let’s say you wanted to see the average immunity in your population:

    immunity <- data.frame(
  immunity = colMeans(rendered$variables[,'immunity',]),
  timestep = 1:100
)
ggplot(
  immunity,
  aes(x = timestep, y = immunity)
) + geom_line()

    And there you have it! We have created an SIR model with immunity and analysed its outputs.
